patient_info:
Lower abdominal pressure and pain right side

Hi I am a 20 year old female. I weigh 163 pounds and I'm 5'4. Body temp is 99.1. I usually range from 96 to 97.I have the iud and have had it for almost a year or a little over 6 months im sure. Got it in spring. The only thing I cam think of having is an ovary problem. My mom has endometriosis and they still havent diagnosed me for anything serious. Gave me the iud without an ultrasound. Right now I have a burning sharp pain in my lower right abdomen. It hurts and keeps me up at night. Feels like something is pushing on my tummy from the inside.  It's becoming hard to move. Turning hurts. Reaching up  and bending down for laundry. Its begging to shoot pain into my leg. Feels like its popping and electric tingles of pain shoot out sometimes. I've been peeing a little more. I have no appetite it seems. Can survive off one small meal a day. I can feel the food go through my intestines and push on whatever is swollen inside. The pain sometime radiates through my back and my side. Havent been going to the bathroom as much as I usually do. I've been diagnosed with chronic constipation when I was in hs and have been using stool softeners to be regular. I'm not sure what's going on and would kml d like some insight. Seems to me that my whole pelvic area Is turning against me
clinical_convo:
Doctor Question: How long has this pain been around?
Patient Response: Been a few days. It's making it hard yea. I remember when it started and it hasn't stopped.

Doctor Question: Any Nausea, vomiting, chills, or fever?
Patient Response: 99.4 fever. Much more gassy and stuff. Pain after I press on the area. Can feel it in my back. My mom touched my leg and I felt pain in my abdomen because she moved my body a bit? Not fun at all. My belly is bloated more.

optionB: Ovarian cyst
optionC: Ectopic pregnancy
optionD: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

Do my (35M) stress echo results mean I have had a prior heart attack

35 years old, white male, 210lbs, 5’9”, 32bmi 

Former smoker - quit 8+ years ago 

Been experience fatigue, headaches, lightheaded, facial flushing, rapid heart beat, High blood pressure 

I had an echo which showed several abnormalities and doctor requested stress echo. I saw the below in the report and don’t speak with him until Tuesday due to the a holiday. Does this mean I likely had a heart attack at some point and didn’t know it? 

ECG
  NSR, normal axis, HR 93 bpm, Q waves in III, AVF suggestive for old inferior MI. Poor R wave progression

Indications: 10 - Cardiomyopathy, Unspecified - I42.9.

optionC: They may be normal variants or minor conduction changes, rather than a past heart attack.

patient_info:
Please, Help me understand blood test results.

Just got my fasted blood test results in my email, obviously my cholesterol is very high, not due to diet or fitness though, so I guess I got the short end of the stick on genetics? :(

---------EDIT--------- Uploaded to Imgur to make easier:



Why are my triglycerides so low while everything else is so high. From what I've read, having an HDL/TRIG ratio of below 2 is very good?

I was hoping my HDL would be higher due to lifting weights and biking.. shafted on that as well.

Also, I thought total cholesterol was LDL + HDL + 1/5th of your Trig?

This is pretty depressing.. the nurse called me with the results, all she read over the phone was the 255 LDL and then said the doctor recommends starting Lipitor immediately. I said I wasn't sure and wanted to think about. The nurse called back 30 mins later to reiterate how important it is that I start a statin immediately and how high of a risk I'm currently at for heart attack/heart disease. It's just hard to hear at 30 years old, 6' 180 pounds, in good shape and extremely thoughtful about what I eat.

 Obviously I need to do something, I'm not in denial, this isn't healthy, and like she said, no amount of exercise or healthy eating (already do both) is going to change it. I'm just afraid of taking the plunge into statins.. but it seems inevitable ?


Of course I've read about read yeast rice, niacin, plant stanols/sterols, etc etc. From what I understand, the most effective - RYR, is very similar to statins in that it's the same compound that works, only at an unknown amount in the RYR? 


What does this other stuff (the non cholesterol stuff) mean to me? What am I doing wrong?

My bilibruin level was half that amount on my non fasted test

I have been on a roll with bad news lately.

** Edit ** - Just opened up the next document from the doctor - results from my neck ultrasound (had 4 little bumps in my neck, 3 on left 1 on right) it says
>the ultrasound of your neck indicates some small lymph nodes. They are not abnormal in appearance. There is no further testing necessary at this time. 

.. So I got that goin for me I guess.
clinical_convo:
Doctor Question: How old are you?
Patient Response: 30
question: Which statement best explains why the doctor strongly recommends statin therapy despite the patient’s low triglyceride levels and healthy lifestyle?
optionA: The lumps in the patient’s neck are likely malignant, necessitating statin therapy as part of the treatment.
optionB: The HDL-to-triglyceride ratio alone is sufficient to evaluate cardiovascular risk, so other cholesterol values can be ignored.
optionC: Despite low triglycerides, the patient’s significantly elevated LDL level puts them at high risk for heart disease, justifying the need for statins.
optionD: A healthy diet and regular exercise are always enough to control severe genetic hypercholesterolemia without medication.

patient_info:
28F, 5'-3", 185lb, No Weight loss with diet and exercise, Thyroid and Vid D def

28, 5'-3" Female with a kid(2 years). I haven't lost my weight since I had the baby, it is currently 185lbs. I have tried exercising(Aerobics, speed walking) for an hour 4 times a week with occasional yoga. My Thyroid is cooked and I am on Synthroid since we found out( Almost 3 years now). I was anaemic during pregnancy and had little/NIL thyroid being produced naturally, but am not Anaemic anymore.

I am controlling my diet considerably. Even after doing exercise over the whole summer, I havent lost even a pound. I know I need to exercise more, but I would want to see some loss with this diet control and exercise.

Current issues as identified by my physician: Hypothyroidism, Vid D def, Vit B12 def, Obesity.

What are my options? What do you think could be reasons with in the current understanding or something out of our approach.
Please, I need your help.
clinical_convo:
Doctor Question: Have you tried a vegan diet?
Patient Response: I will think of this option ,added to my to-do list. Thanks.

patient_info:
36/F - Felt like UTI, clinic doc said no

I'm 36/F and have controlled hypothyroidism and occasional candidiasis.  I normally only take Synthroid 50 and Celexa 10 daily, along with Klonopin as needed.  I've recently finished two rounds of Amoxicillin and Norco for a tooth infection.

Symptoms began a couple of weeks ago with a feeling of irritation that I normally associate with UTI.  Water and cranberry pills didn't help and I'd begun to have frequent urination, so I went to urgent care over the weekend.  The doctor found no trace of a UTI or any other problem, but gave me medication for my tooth (more Amoxicillin), told me it might help the UTI, and if not he'd refer me to a urologist.

My condition worsened and I began drinking more water, taking cranberry pills, D-mannose and aloe juice throughout the day, while also adding a women's health probiotic.  Things began to clear up for me right before my period.  When my period went away, some symptoms seemed to return.

I currently have weird irritation after urination.  I seem to urinate a bit more than usual, but not as much as before my period.  Sitting for long periods of time makes my vulva/urethra feel uncomfortable.  It honestly feels like whatever I had isn't as bad in some ways and is worse in others.

I haven't been sexually active in a year and a half and have only masturbated once since the issue began.  I only stimulated my clitoris, but I feel it may have irritated the area further.

I am waiting on a call back from the gynecologist, but I'd love some opinions on what might be wrong and anything I can potentially do to minimize the annoying discomfort.

Thank you!

*Edit:*  I visited urgent care this morning, due to no free appointments at my PCP.  I was diagnosed with a UTI and given Cirpro.  Thanks for the help!
clinical_convo:
Doctor Question: Why not pursue that referral?
Patient Response: I didn't pursue it initially because the condition did slightly improve for a seven day period and I was a bit concerned about evasive procedures that could come with a urologist. I had a nasty experience with a specialist a couple of years ago, so I thought I'd see if probiotics and other natural supplements could help. That was definitely an error on my part.
question: Which of the following best describes the patient's main reason for not immediately pursuing the referral to a urologist recommended by her urgent care doctor?
optionA: She was not sure about the doctor’s competence.
optionB: She already had an appointment with her primary care physician.
optionC: She worried about invasive procedures due to a past negative experience.
optionD: She was advised by her dentist to wait until her tooth infection had completely cleared.

patient_info:
Cleaned up mercury thermometer spill, some of it still caught between tiles in floor. Should I be concerned?

* 22
* Male
* A little under Six Feet Tall.
* 155-ish lbs/70-ish Kg.
* Latinoamerican
* Not taking anything at the moment.

So last night, I was feeling kinda queasy and had a weird cough, so I decided to take my temperature with a mercury thermometer I had. After doing that, I accidentally dropped it and it broke on the tile floor. None of it got on me, and I spent the next 30-40 minutes cleaning it up (wearing latex gloves and avoiding any contact with the mercury if possible, mostly used ziploc bags and tissue paper, though I think some of it did touch my hands a couple times, after which I washed my hands with hot water and a ton of soap for about 3 to 4 minutes, about three times, don't have any rashes or anything on my hands). 

After I was done, I put all the things I used to clean up with on a small plastic bag and I put that in a larger trash bag, took it out and threw it in the landfill tub outside my apartment. After I got back, I noticed some tiny droplets were caught between the tiles, deep enough that I couldn't move them with anything I had. I've left the living room windows open all night (this happened roughly at 11:30 last night) to vent the room, and I checked this morning and the small droplets are still there, but look noticeably smaller. I slept in my bedroom with the door closed and have stayed away from the living room so far, mostly just going there a couple times to check if the droplets are still lodged between the tiles.

My question is, should I be worried about having inhaled or otherwise been exposed to dangerous amounts of mercury overnight? Should I be concerned about mercury poisoning?

And, most importantly, should I be concerned about the tiny droplets between the tiles? We're talking small enough that I only noticed them by shining a flashlight right on top of them.
clinical_convo:
Doctor Question: Are you 100% sure it was a mercury thermometer?
Patient Response: Positive. I brought it with me from Chile when I came into the country in a small first aid pack I got from a pharmacy. We still use those there, I believe. Plus the liquid on the floor looked and acted like mercury. It was a shiny liquid that slid off most surfaces and congregated in blobs.
question: Which of the following is the best next step in addressing the small droplets of mercury still lodged between the floor tiles?
optionA: Vacuum the area thoroughly with a household vacuum cleaner.
optionB: Mop the floor using hot water and bleach to dissolve any remaining mercury.
optionC: Keep the area well ventilated, avoid vacuuming or sweeping, and follow local mercury spill guidance if necessary.
optionD: Ignore the droplets since they are too small to cause any harm, letting them evaporate on their own.

patient_info:
Tonsil Stones??

So for YEARS I’ve had chronic sore throat, sinus issues, ear aches, trouble breathing, etc. I’m not implying causality with the following scenario but I’m thinking it’s a possibility? Anyway, it’s never been so bad that I couldn’t just deal with it given the occasional day off to rest and recover. Well randomly tonight I was having a rough time. I looked at my throat and saw white spots. Naturally, I thought, “CRAP, strep!”.  Just so happens I was with someone who second guessed me and took a look for himself. He told me he’d had this issue and that it was tonsil stones. We proceeded to extract not one but NINE motherlovin’ nasty ass stones from my tonsils. And that’s just what we could catch on q-tips-not including the ones (larger than the ones we swabbed, probably 6-7 in number) I coughed/vomited up. Needless to say, I’m thoroughly grossed/freaked out. Hopefully I can now justify having my tonsils removed. Would this be enough to justify a tonsillectomy? I’m also wondering about the underlying cause. I am very meticulous with my oral hygiene and my diet. I am an otherwise very healthy, active 26 y/o female. I’m having a minor meltdown at 3 am. Haaaalp!
clinical_convo:
Doctor Question: Have you ever been to an ENT for your issues?
Patient Response: Thank you very much for the info. I will definitely be making an appointment with an ENT! I can deal with sore throats but these nasty little things are too much.
question: Which statement best addresses whether frequently occurring tonsil stones and chronic throat discomfort may justify a tonsillectomy for this patient?
optionA: A tonsillectomy is only considered for strep infections, so multiple stones alone would not be an indication.
optionB: If the patient experiences recurrent symptoms and significant discomfort, an ENT might recommend a tonsillectomy.
optionC: Regular saltwater gargles are always enough to prevent tonsil stones and make surgery unnecessary.
optionD: Tonsil stones are harmless and do not require any further assessment or treatment by a specialist.

patient_info:
Question about broken right tibfib surgery

Hello, I am a 30 year old woman, I just had my first car accident ever on Saturday October the 7th thanks to someone running a stop sign. I ended up with a very badly broken leg, they said it was the tibfib, it was floppy and so very painful. Well, they didn't really take care of me at the hospital, I received no pain management until after I had surgery, but I am getting off topic. The surgeon came and told me he was putting a rod in the big one, the tibula, and not doing anything for the other one saying it will set itself right. After the surgery it didn't feel right while I was there. I was discharged 2 days later and it still doesn't feel right, it's kind of grindy feeling when I am setting my pillows up to prop my leg. A friend who had the same thing got a rod in both bones and said I should seek a second opinion. Is only one rod normal? 

Other stuff, I am 5'6" at 215lbs, when I was discharged I was told absolutely no weight on my foot and was given a walker, which I hate.
clinical_convo:
Doctor Question: How far from surgery are you now?
Patient Response: The accident was October 7th, presumably you just had surgery and were discharged today or yesterday.

Doctor Question: I'm sure the nurse or doc would have given you instructions on how to take care of and clean your leg at home?
Patient Response: No, they gave me 3 page discharge packet and it most covered what I had done and my medication.

Doctor Question: If it's tight to the point of cutting off circulation or extreme discomfort you should loosen it of course....
Patient Response: None
question: Which statement best reflects the typical management of a tib-fib fracture when only the tibia is surgically stabilized with a rod?
optionA: It is recommended to place rods in both the tibia and fibula for every tib-fib fracture.
optionB: A single rod in the tibia is usually inadequate, so further surgery is essential.
optionC: If the fibula is minimally displaced, fixing only the tibia can be a normal approach.
optionD: A cast or brace alone is usually sufficient for most tib-fib fractures.

patient_info:
Very concerned about my daughter

Hello,

My 3 year old daughter hasn't slept in two days. She has become EXTREMELY anxious out of nowhere, and she also happens to be constipated. We are in California.

Context(?):
On Tue night (today is Sun), we both had some flu symptoms. Mine went away within 12 hours with a broken out sweat at around 5am. She seemed to still be sick, but better, so I sent her to school. When I went to pick her up from preschool, the teacher said that she was acting very different/off and asking to sleep a lot, which made sense since we were both sick. She seemed better/not a concern by Thursday night.

Anyways, on Friday night I was woken up by her nonstop throughout the night. Probably 8-9 times of her just acting slightly out of character. She was asking for things she usually asks of me to help get her back down, but way too frequently and definitely got little to no sleep Fri night.

Last night (Sat) when I got home, my wife was ready to take her to the ER because she was apparently acting super strangely. She had spoken to the advice nurse and they recommend we go in, so we did. She was screaming/irrational/totally a wreck the whole time, and overly anxious of things that made no sense to be anxious about. We get home around 1:30-2 AM and I laid with her all night trying to get her to sleep.

As soon as she would be calm for a moment and start to relax, she jets up at full speed hyperventilating for a few breaths. She was worried about everything. Even her pillow eating her. She is acting schizo, and I couldn't be more concerned. She won't even drink out of a cup because she's worried about it spilling (she drinks out of cups all the time). But it's so bad that she hyperventilates and curls up in a ball if you try to bring the cup close to her. She is saying very weird things, and acting like a scary kid out of a movie with deadpan, ominous thoughts. 

Last night, she kept saying she needed to poo but didn't at all, but also didn't pee at all either, and hasn't for a good amount of time.

Any insights??

Update: It was not encephalitis! Just an post-infectious auto-immune response. Super random, can happen to anyone after a virus I guess. But, she is clear and doing much better!!

patient_info:
17M Alternative medicine:

So my mom is on the alternative medicine side, while I'm the exact opposite. This week I got a common cold and she wanted me to use colloidal silver, which I refuse because silver is poisonous(?).  Yesterday when my cold became more of a cough. She apparently read in some book from some professor that for disinfection one should pour a drop of Hydrochloric acid and another drop of Sodium chlorite, cover the glass, wait a minute and then lightly inhale once through the nose, once through the mouth. I find these two things really weird and unusual and I don't trust them, that's why I haven't used any and got into a fight with my mom. Would someone please be willing to give me more information or what you think of these practices? Thank you

I'm sorry I couldn't get more info but she literally refuses to tell me more.

Existing issues:
 - headaches: most likely due to change I air pressure and I usually take 500g paracetamol, sleep it out or hot shower
- heart defect:Quadcuspid Aortic Vavlue (instead of tricuspid) seems healthy/normal otherwise but need to follow up once every 1-2 years 

Background: I went snowboarding on Monday after just beginning the slope (within the very first 5-6 seconds) my board bit the snow and I fell on snow (no rocks), with my chest and only my chest breaking my fall (idk why my hands didn't break the fall).

So, ever since that day, nearly every thing I do hurts, and is probably the most painful thing I have felt in my life, more than being kicked in the balls.
It doesn't matter if I breathe deeply, laugh or try to move my upper body in any way, it hurts like hell. It seems to slightly get better throughout the day, but after a nights sleep (on my back) all the pain comes back with full force; so much that it literally takes me 5 min to slowly get the courage to get out of bed because that is one of the worst moments thb. No visible signs of injury afaik.

I went to my emergency center (in Sweden, närakute) and the doctor only listened to my breathing, to see if my lungs were punctured, and then prescribed me some anti inflammatory (idk the name but she said twice a day with food). I just checked her notes online and all she wrote was: "Contusion on the chest". 


Obviously I'm not a doctor or anything else, but shouldn't I actually get a fucking xray at the very least or something? I mean maybe if something else is punctured or bleeding, then I'd actually be dead by now from internal bleeding, but still, how can this hurt so much without something being broken?
clinical_convo:
Doctor Question: If you're genuinely concerned and would like an x-ray you could always go back and ask them for one, I'm not sure how health care works in Sweden though so sorry if I'm wrong
Patient Response: None

Doctor Question: If not, or if there is intense pain that remains along the spine, I would definitely go to see someone.
Patient Response: None
question: Based on the conversation, which best explains why the doctor likely did not order an X-ray for this chest injury?
optionA: The doctor believed the patient required an immediate CT scan for an accurate diagnosis.
optionB: The clinical evaluation suggested a contusion without signs of serious injury, so imaging was not mandatory.
optionC: Swedish law prohibits X-rays for chest injuries unless recommended by a radiologist.
optionD: The patient specifically refused any radiological examinations at the time.

- heart defect:Quadcuspid Aortic Vavlue (instead of tricuspid) seems healthy/normal otherwise but need to follow up once every 1-2 years
Background: I went snowboarding on Monday after just beginning the slope (within the very first 5-6 seconds) my board bit the snow and I fell on snow (no rocks), with my chest and only my chest breaking my fall (idk why my hands didn't break the fall).
So, ever since that day, nearly every thing I do hurts, and is probably the most painful thing I have felt in my life, more than being kicked in the balls.
It doesn't matter if I breathe deeply, laugh or try to move my upper body in any way, it hurts like hell. It seems to slightly get better throughout the day, but after a nights sleep (on my back) all the pain comes back with full force; so much that it literally takes me 5 min to slowly get the courage to get out of bed because that is one of the worst moments thb. No visible signs of injury afaik.
I went to my emergency center (in Sweden, närakute) and the doctor only listened to my breathing, to see if my lungs were punctured, and then prescribed me some anti inflammatory (idk the name but she said twice a day with food). I just checked her notes online and all she wrote was: "Contusion on the chest".

Obviously I'm not a doctor or anything else, but shouldn't I actually get a fucking xray at the very least or something? I mean maybe if something else is punctured or bleeding, then I'd actually be dead by now from internal bleeding, but still, how can this hurt so much without something being broken?

Question Based on the conversation, which best explains why the doctor likely did not order an X-ray for this chest injury?
Options
A. The doctor believed the patient required an immediate CT scan for an accurate diagnosis.
